nodes.text: Infinite exponential economic growth is essential and must be sustained for the conservation and survival of human civilization

Both dominant perspectives on growth (anti-growth centered on entropy constraints and pro-growth centered on mental/knowledge exceptionalism) are limited, subjective, and insufficient to resolve the controversy

The universal process of creation (equilibration producing new levels of organization and disequilibrium) is the central mechanism that generates value, knowledge, and exponential increases in organizational power
Economic growth is fundamentally about value creation, which is the production of radical novelty via the process of creation and the emergence of new levels of organization
Policy prescriptions that constrain production, consumption, or population without engaging the process of creation will fail and may cause system disintegration
Anti-growth perspective overemphasizes entropy as ontologically primary and treats entropy only as destructive depletion, ignoring its role in producing new organization and disequilibrium
Pro-growth advocates wrongly treat mental/knowledge production as exempt from entropy and base their argument on an unjustified dualism between mind and matter
Equilibration (entropy production) both dissipates resources at one organizational level and creates new, more powerful levels of organization that open access to new resources
The combinatoric dynamics of operations at a level (n operations producing approximately n squared combinations) yields exponential increases in possibilities and organizational power

Mental operations and knowledge production are subject to resource constraints and forms of entropy (including depletion of disequilibrium), so knowledge production shows diminishing research productivity without creating new higher levels

Translating exponential increases in mental organizational power into material economic production is necessary to conserve the global level of human organization and prevent resource underutilization

Empirical evidence: studies (e.g., Bloom et al.) show research productivity per researcher falls over time and maintaining constant GDP-per-person growth requires exponential increases in research effort, supporting the claim that knowledge production faces increasing difficulty without new organizational levels

Theoretical critique and conceptual method: close analysis of definitions (economic activity, value, value creation), thermodynamics, evolutionary/combinatoric logic, and literature synthesis form the methodological basis for the argument
